children: A 72-year-old man with COPD is evaluated for acute cough, fever, and dyspnea.
Chest
radiographs
are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is right upper lobe pneumonia. The posteroanterior chest radiograph shows an alveolar infiltrate in the right upper lung zone that obliterates the ascending aorta. The lateral chest radiograph shows an infiltrate in the superior lung field anterior to the major fissure. These findings are most consistent with a right upper lobe infiltrate (pneumonia).

title: Question 2

children: A 41-year-old man is evaluated for the skin rash
shown
. He lives in Florida. One week ago, he removed a Lone Star tick from his arm.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is Southern tick–associated rash illness (STARI). STARI presents with erythema migrans lesions identical to those seen in Lyme disease but without clinical progression or complications. STARI is associated with
Amblyomma americanum
, also known as the Lone Star tick, and occurs in the southeastern, south-central, and eastern United States; Lyme disease is transmitted by
Ixodes

ticks and is more likely to occur in the northeastern and north-central United States. No infectious cause of STARI has been confirmed. Therefore, diagnosis is based on clinical and geographic features. Because STARI and early-stage Lyme disease may be clinically indistinguishable, treatment with doxycycline is recommended.

figureCredits: Image courtesy of Dr. Karen Bloch.

children: A 65-year-old woman is evaluated for severe pain on the right side of the upper chest of 1 week's duration and was followed by the appearance of the rash
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is herpes zoster. Reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus causes herpes zoster, or shingles. Prodromal symptoms, such as burning, stinging, or tingling, often occur in a localized region, followed by a dermatomal eruption of grouped vesicles or pustules on an erythematous base. The most common dermatomes affected are in the thoracic region.
A 19-year-old woman is evaluated for meningitis. She is a college student living in a dormitory.
A cerebrospinal fluid Gram stain specimen is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely causative agent?
The most likely causative agent is
Neisseria meningitidis.
The image demonstrates gram-negative diplococci that are semicircular and have flattened opposing sides, a finding characteristic
of N. meningitidis.
Where available, multiplex polymerase chain reaction assay is a preferred method for detection of
N. meningitidis, Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae,
and
Listeria monocytogenes,
because it has high sensitivity and specificity and allows more rapid diagnosis than does culture.

objective.__html: Recognize Neisseria meningitidis in a cerebrospinal fluid Gram stain specimen.

title: Question 5

children: A 38-year-old woman is evaluated for the acute onset of fever, headache, and sore throat that began 5 days ago. Two days ago, a rash developed on her face and then spread to her proximal extremities.
The rash on her leg is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

This patient has smallpox. Patients initially present with high fever, malaise, vomiting, headache, backache, and severe abdominal pain several days before the onset of the skin eruption. In the ordinary (classic) form of smallpox, the lesions are synchronous (all in the same stage of development), begin on the oral mucosa and face, and are followed by cutaneous spread to the arms, legs, hands and feet, and trunk. The lesions usually evolve from macules to papules to pustules and finally to scabs. The last reported case of smallpox worldwide occurred in 1977; any new case represents evidence of a bioterrorism attack.

figureCredits: Image reproduced from the CDC Public Health Image Library.

title: Question 6

children: A 31-year-old man is evaluated for the acute onset of skin lesions on his inner thighs, as
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Pink papules and pustules centered on hair follicles are characteristic of folliculitis. The beard, pubic areas, axillae, and thighs are often affected; however, it can appear on any hair-bearing area of skin. Folliculitis can be noninfectious (HIV-associated eosinophilic folliculitis) or infectious. The most frequent cause of infectious folliculitis is
Staphylococcus aureus

figureCredits: Image reproduced from the CDC Public Health Image Library.

children: A 51-year-old woman is evaluated for blurred vision, floaters, and photopsia. All symptoms are restricted to the right eye. She has untreated HIV infection.
Funduscopic examination findings are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is cytomegalovirus retinitis. Cytomegalovirus retinitis in this patient with HIV infection is characterized by yellow-white, fluffy, or granular retinal lesions, often located close to retinal vessels and associated with hemorrhage. Cytomegalovirus retinitis most often presents unilaterally but can become bilateral in the absence of treatment.

Approximately 60% to 90% of adults have latent cytomegalovirus infection, with reactivation of disease more common in immunosuppressed persons (such as those with AIDS, transplant recipients, and those receiving glucocorticoids). Cytomegalovirus can cause retinitis, pneumonitis, hepatitis, bone marrow suppression, colitis, esophagitis, and adrenalitis in immunocompromised persons.
A 50-year-old man is evaluated for chronic cough, fever, and weight loss. He recently emigrated from Vietnam.
A Ziehl-Neelsen stain of a sputum specimen is
shown
Which of the following organisms is most likely present on this patient's sputum specimen?
The image demonstrates a positive acid-fast (Ziehl-Neelsen) stain for mycobacteria, specifically
Mycobacterium tuberculosis
, showing characteristic thin bacilli that stain red on a blue background.

objective.__html: Recognize a positive acid-fast stain for a Mycobacterium species.

children: A 56-year-old man is evaluated for fever, chills, and a rapidly spreading, warm and painful skin condition
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Cellulitis is a rapidly spreading, deep, subcutaneous-based infection characterized by a well-demarcated area of warmth, swelling, tenderness, and erythema that may be accompanied by lymphatic streaking and/or fever and chills. Cellulitis is often caused by streptococci or staphylococci.

title: Question 10

children: A 30-year-old man is evaluated for fever, arthralgia, myalgia, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and development of the rash
shown
. He returned from an extended stay in the Indian subcontinent 2 weeks ago.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is enteric fever. This patient has a characteristic rash, which appears as discrete, blanching, 1- to 4-mm salmon-colored macules (rose spots) that develop in crops on the chest and abdomen. The rash develops in about 20% of patients during the second week of illness.
Salmonella enterica
serotype Typhi and
S. enterica

Paratyphi (A, B, and C) cause prolonged febrile and often serious infection (typhoid fever and paratyphoid fever). Infection is acquired by consuming food or water contaminated by organisms shed in the stool of infected humans. The disease is characterized by the gradual onset of fever with headache, arthralgia, myalgia, pharyngitis, and anorexia that follows a 1- to 2-week incubation period. Abdominal pain and tenderness can be accompanied by early-onset diarrhea, which may spontaneously resolve or become severe late in disease. Twenty percent of patients have constipation at diagnosis. In untreated illness, temperature progressively increases and may remain elevated (up to 40 °C [104 °F]) for 4 to 8 weeks. A pulse-temperature dissociation (relative bradycardia) and prostration are common.

figureCredits: Image reproduced from the CDC Public Health Image Library.

children: A 40-year-old man with recently diagnosed HIV infection is evaluated for painful mouth lesions. The
lesions
can be scraped off using a tongue blade.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Oropharyngeal candidiasis (thrush) is characterized by painful, white, curd-like discrete plaques on an erythematous base, typically located on the buccal mucosa, throat, tongue, and gingivae. The white surface of the plaques can be scraped off. A Gram stain or potassium hydroxide preparation on the scrapings will reveal budding yeasts with or without hyphae. Risk factors for oral candidiasis include immunosuppression, diabetes mellitus, use of antibiotics, oral and inhaled glucocorticoids, and smoking.

title: Question 12

children: A 29-year-old man who works as a professional landscaper is evaluated for the skin lesions
shown
Which of the following infections is the most likely diagnosis?
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is sporotrichosis, which is caused by the fungus
Sporothrix schenckii. S. schenckii

lives in soil, moss, or other organic material frequently used in gardening and landscaping. The most common presentation of sporotrichosis is lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis. The primary lesion is located at the site of inoculation (in this case, over the fourth metacarpophalangeal joint) and consists of an ulcerated nodule. Similar lesions occur proximally along the lymphatics (in this case, up the arm).
Sporotrichosis can also present as a plaque-like or verrucous-like lesion that typically appears on the face, as
shown
on the tip of the nose of this child. Extracutaneous infection (osteoarticular, pulmonary, ocular, or disseminated) can occur in immunocompromised hosts.

figureCredits: Image in the critique reproduced from the CDC Public Health Image Library.

children: A 52-year-old woman is evaluated for fever and severe headache.
Brain MRI with contrast is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is a brain abscess. On MRI, early cerebritis appears as an irregular area of low density that does not enhance after contrast injection. As cerebritis evolves, the lesion enlarges with thick and diffuse ring enhancement after contrast injection, as
seen

in this patient. The ring of contrast enhancement represents a breakdown of the blood-brain barrier and the development of an inflammatory capsule. Aspiration of the brain abscess for culture is preferred for definitive diagnosis; surgical or stereotactic drainage should be performed if the abscess is large (>2.5 cm).

objective.__html: Diagnose a brain abscess based on MRI findings.

children: A 48-year-old man with alcoholic cirrhosis is evaluated for a rapidly progressive cellulitis 4 days after sustaining minor lacerations on his fingers while opening oysters.
Skin findings are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely infectious agent?
This patient has rapidly progressing necrotizing fasciitis caused by
Vibrio vulnificus
infection.
V. vulnificus

is found in warm waters throughout the world and is responsible for many serious infections in the United States each year as a result of exposure to shellfish and seawater, especially in patients with cirrhosis or other liver diseases.
A 25-year-old woman is evaluated for altered mentation, fever, and new-onset seizures.
Brain MRI scan is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is herpes simplex encephalitis. This patient's MRI scan reveals hyperintense areas in the left temporal lobe and insular area. Temporal lobe lesions are suggestive of herpes simplex encephalitis; lesions are predominantly unilateral and may have associated mass effects. MRI is the most sensitive and specific imaging method for diagnosing herpes simplex encephalitis, especially early in the disease course, although normal MRI findings have also been reported. Cranial CT of the brain has only 50% sensitivity early in the disease.
A 61-year-old man is evaluated for fever, cough, hypoxic respiratory failure, and a pulmonary infiltrate. He produces a sputum specimen for Gram
stain
Which of the following is most consistent with this patient's sputum sample?

This is a poor-quality sputum specimen, with squamous epithelial cells as well as a mixed population of organisms, most suggestive of contamination with oropharyngeal secretions and organisms. The image
shown

below demonstrates a good sputum specimen with many neutrophils and no squamous epithelial cells; the organisms in this stain are both gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria of multiple morphologies, an appearance that is most consistent with an anaerobic infection resulting from aspiration of organisms in the oropharynx.
A 31-year-old woman is evaluated for the recent development of painless growths on her
vulva
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is condyloma acuminata (genital warts). Condyloma acuminata can manifest as single or multiple growths of varied forms, including but not limited to flat or plaque-like, dome-like, finger-like, pedunculated, and cauliflower-shaped. They may be white, flesh colored, pink or red, or even brown. Genital human papillomavirus (HPV) infections are the most common sexually transmitted infection, with more than 1 million cases diagnosed each year. HPV infections most commonly manifest as genital or extragenital warts. Condyloma acuminata refers specifically to genital warts caused by HPV.

objective.__html: Diagnose the causative agent for genital warts.

children: A 56-year-old man is evaluated for hemoptysis. He has a past history of previously treated cavitary tuberculosis.
An enlarged image from a frontal radiograph is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
This enlarged image from a frontal chest radiograph
shows
a fungus ball (in this case, an aspergilloma). A cavitary lesion (
arrowheads
) contains a roughly round mass (
arrow
). The mass represents a fungus ball (also termed a mycetoma or, when caused by the fungus
Aspergillus,

an aspergilloma) and consists of fungal hyphae and cellular debris. A fungus ball typically appears to be separated from the wall of the surrounding cavity and may move when the patient is imaged in a different position. Fungus balls form in cavitary lesions of the lung, most often present owing to conditions such as tuberculosis, bronchiectasis, carcinoma, or lung abscesses. They may be asymptomatic or present with complications, such as hemoptysis.
A 21-year-old man develops an acute, painful skin lesion on the left lateral
thigh
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is a staphylococcal abscess. Abscesses are soft tissue infections composed of collections of pus and bacteria within the dermis and subcutaneous tissue. A staphylococcal abscess typically presents as a tender, erythematous, fluctuant nodule topped by a central pustule.

A 52-year-old man is evaluated for fever, hypotension, and rash. The rash was preceded by cutaneous pain, followed by the development of petechial lesions that coalesced, forming ecchymoses and evolving into the changes
shown
Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for this patient's skin findings?
Neisseria meningitidis

is the most likely causative agent for this patient's skin findings. Skin lesions begin as petechia but can evolve to purpura. Purpura fulminans is a severe complication of meningococcal disease. Meningococcal-induced microvascular thrombosis and disseminated intravascular coagulation can lead to widespread hemorrhage into the skin, which can evolve into painful purple geographic lesions. The lesions may become necrotic, with the formation of bullae and vesicles.

objective.__html: Diagnose purpura fulminans and its association with meningococcemia.

children: A 21-year-old woman is evaluated for the acute onset of painful genital and perianal lesions. HIV
testing
results are positive.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is herpes simplex virus infection. Classically, herpes simplex virus type 2 infection can cause genital herpes and usually presents as a cluster of painful, pink papules that rapidly become vesicular. In immunosuppressed patients, such as those with HIV infection, the presentation may be atypical and may include features such as nodules or nonhealing ulcers, as seen in this patient.

title: Question 22

children: A 51-year-old man is evaluated for fever, headache, and anemia. He recently returned from an extended tour of the Amazon River.
Peripheral blood smear is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
The most likely diagnosis is malaria. This patient's peripheral smear shows red blood cells infected with
Plasmodium vivax;
the trophozoite of
P. vivax

is ameboid shaped, and the enlarged infected erythrocyte contains numerous Schuffner dots. Diagnosis of malaria is made by identification of malarial parasites on the peripheral blood smear. Morphologic features help determine the specific species. Multiple sets of peripheral blood smears may be needed from patients to isolate malaria with low degrees of parasitemia. Rapid tests that detect malaria antigens are available but may lack sensitivity and specificity. Polymerase chain reaction and serologic assays exist, although each has limitations.

objective.__html: Diagnose malaria based on peripheral blood smear findings.

figureCredits: Image reproduced from the CDC Public Health Image Library.

children: A 40-year-old man who recently emigrated from Argentina is evaluated for several weeks of headache, nausea and vomiting, and new-onset seizures.
Head CT
scans
are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is neurocysticercosis. This patient's head CT scan shows obstructive hydrocephalus and multiple cystic lesions in the lateral ventricle caused by neurocysticercosis. Cysticercosis is caused by the larval stage of the pork tapeworm,
Taenia solium

. Neurocysticercosis is endemic in Mexico, South America, and Asia. There are parenchymal and extraparenchymal subtypes. It most commonly presents with seizures or hydrocephalus. Head CT scan shows multiple cysts or calcified lesions.
A 23-year-old man is evaluated for weight loss, fever, and night sweats. Symptoms have progressed over 6 weeks. He is incarcerated.
Chest radiograph is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
The most likely diagnosis is miliary tuberculosis. The chest radiograph
shows
the bilateral presence of innumerable 1- to 3-mm nodules, predominantly seen within the lower lung fields (
black arrows

). These findings, although not specific, are typical of dissemination of tuberculosis through the vasculature or the lymphatic vessels. The small nodules have been likened to millet seeds, from which the term
miliary
is derived. Slight lower lobe predominance is likely a result of the effects of gravity on blood flow.
A 58-year-old man is evaluated for ventilator-associated pneumonia.
A sputum specimen is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely sputum finding?
The most likely sputum finding is
Candida
species. The image demonstrates pseudohyphae and budding yeast forms, which are characteristic of
Candida
. Although
Candida
species can involve the lung as part of a disseminated infection,
Candida
is a rare cause of primary pneumonia and usually represents colonization when isolated from a sputum sample.
Aspergillus fumigatus
shows acutely branching hyphae with septations.
Blastomyces dermatitidis
is seen as large, round, budding yeast with a broad base.
Coccidioides immitis
is identified by evidence of thick-walled, round structures.
Mucor
species have broad, irregularly branched hyphae without septations.

objective.__html: Diagnose Candida species in a sputum specimen.

children: A 45-year-old woman is evaluated for a painless
lesion
on her arm. She processes animal hides from Africa to make traditional drums.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is cutaneous anthrax. Cutaneous lesions are initially pruritic and painless and subsequently progress to vesicular lesions surrounded by nonpitting edema. The lesions then become hemorrhagic or necrotic, and satellite lesions may form. Finally, a central black eschar can develop, which usually resolves over 6 weeks. Diagnosis is confirmed by culture of blood or exudate or by full-thickness skin biopsy.

Although naturally occurring anthrax is rare in the United States, sporadic outbreaks periodically occur in wild and domestic grazing animals, such as deer or cattle, in areas where spores exist in contaminated soil, plants, or water (e.g., the Western United States). Infection can also occur in persons who process contaminated animal hides. Cutaneous anthrax is the most common type of anthrax in the United States and develops when causative microorganisms are introduced into a skin abrasion or cut.
A 66-year-old woman is evaluated for high fever, cough, sputum production, and a pulmonary infiltrate following a recent diagnosis of influenza.
A sputum Gram stain specimen is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely causative agent?
The image demonstrates gram-positive cocci in clusters, which are characteristic of
Staphylococcus aureus.
Influenza and other respiratory viral infections can be a risk factor for secondary bacterial infection; a common complication of influenza is pneumonia.

objective.__html: Diagnose Staphylococcus aureus in a sputum Gram stain specimen.

children: A 38-year-old man is evaluated for a 2-day history of right arm pain, erythema, and fever following a traumatic injury to the arm 5 days ago.
Radiograph of the right arm is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
The most likely diagnosis is necrotizing fasciitis. The plain radiograph shows subcutaneous gas, suggesting necrotizing fasciitis resulting from traumatic inoculation of
Clostridia

into the subcutaneous tissues. Noncontrast CT may also be helpful in detecting gas and delineating the extent of involvement; MRI with contrast is more sensitive for visualizing soft-tissue involvement but less sensitive for detecting gas. However, imaging should not delay surgery when clinical suspicion is high. Penetrating traumatic wounds with vascular compromise are particularly prone to gas gangrene because they establish an anaerobic environment that encourages growth of
Clostridia
. These organisms produce toxins that lead to rapid and widespread tissue necrosis and systemic toxicity.

objective.__html: Identify subcutaneous gas characteristic of type III necrotizing fasciitis on a plain radiograph.

title: Question 29

children: A 28-year-old woman is evaluated for fever, generalized lymphadenopathy, and the rash
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is secondary syphilis, which develops 2 to 8 weeks after the appearance of the primary chancre and is characterized by widespread hematogenous dissemination involving many organs, most often the skin, liver, and lymph nodes. The skin findings of secondary syphilis consist of a generalized mucocutaneous rash; involvement of the palms and soles is characteristic. The rash takes various morphologic forms, except for vesicular. Generalized lymphadenopathy and constitutional symptoms also occur.

figureCredits: Image reproduced from the CDC Public Health Image Library.

children: A 35-year-old woman is evaluated for a 1-week history of chills and altered mental status and a 2-week history of fever and severe headache. She has recently been diagnosed with HIV infection.
An India ink preparation of the spun cerebrospinal fluid sediment is
shown
Which of the following organisms is most likely present?
Cryptococcus neoformans
is present in this patient's cerebrospinal fluid specimen. The image demonstrates how India ink can outline the clear capsule around a yeast form of
C. neoformans. C. neoformans

is inhaled and causes an initial pulmonary infection. Healthy persons generally contain the initial infection because of intact cell-mediated immunity; however, immunocompromised persons are at risk for dissemination. Risk factors for dissemination include AIDS, organ transplantation, glucocorticoid treatment, diabetes mellitus, liver dysfunction, and kidney injury. The central nervous system is the most common site of disseminated cryptococcosis. This patient most likely has cryptococcal meningitis, as evidenced by the triad of headache, fever, and positive India ink preparation of the cerebrospinal fluid; however, the sensitivity of India ink positivity varies in different patient populations. Serum cryptococcal antigen is positive in greater than 95% of infected patients and should be obtained in all patients to confirm the diagnosis.

objective.__html: Diagnose Cryptococcus neoformans meningitis based on an India ink preparation of a cerebrospinal fluid specimen.

children: A 28-year-old man is evaluated for the skin lesions
shown
. He is found to be HIV positive.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient's skin lesions?

This patient most likely has Kaposi sarcoma. Lesions can present as erythematous or violaceous macules or larger nodules and plaques that may ulcerate. Early lesions may be characterized by palpable nodules that occur before skin discoloration develops. Common sites include the face, trunk, and lower extremities. Kaposi sarcoma is caused by human herpesvirus 8, occurs almost exclusively in HIV-infected individuals (most commonly in men who have sex with men), and may appear before the CD4 cell count becomes suppressed.

title: Question 32

children: A 26-year-old woman is evaluated for fever, painful tenosynovitis, migratory polyarthralgia, and the skin lesions
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Disseminated gonococcal infection is the diagnosis most consistent with this patient's skin finding. It is commonly associated with pustular or vesiculopustular skin lesions (but macules, papules, and bullae are also possible), which are typically found on the distal extremities. The rash is often painless and may only last a few days. These lesions are typically associated with tenosynovitis and polyarthralgia and often are associated with systemic signs, such as fever.

figureCredits: Image reproduced from the CDC Public Health Image Library.

title: Question 33

children: A 49-year-old previously well woman is evaluated for fever, malaise, and an acute eruption that began on her face and trunk and then spread to her extremities, as
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is primary varicella-zoster virus infection. The skin lesions of primary varicella-zoster infection (chickenpox) progress over hours from erythematous macules and papules to vesicles. Vesicles often develop a pustular component (as seen in this patient), which then form crusted papules. Vesicles at various stages of evolution are found on the skin. Typically, new batches of lesions appear every few days, originate on the face and trunk, and spread to the extremities, resulting in a "centripetal" pattern of spread. The rash is frequently accompanied by a low-grade fever and malaise.

figureCredits: Image reproduced from the CDC Public Health Image Library.

title: Question 34

children: A 45-year-old man is evaluated for dysuria and urethral discharge.
Microscopic examination of the urethral discharge is
shown
Which of the following organisms is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
The organism that is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms is
Neisseria gonorrhoeae
. This image demonstrates gram-negative, intracellular diplococci, a finding characteristic of
N. gonorrhoeae
(gonococcus). Men with urethritis present with dysuria, urethral pruritus, and discharge. Mucopurulent discharge may be the only symptom and is clinically diagnostic.
N. gonorrhoeae
Chlamydia trachomatis
, and
Mycoplasma genitalium
are common causes of urethritis;
Trichomonas
may present similarly to other causes of infectious urethritis.

objective.__html: Diagnose Neisseria gonorrhoeae on Gram stain of a urethral discharge sample.

figureCredits: Image reproduced from the CDC Public Health Image Library.

title: Question 35

children: A 23-year-old man is evaluated for painful genital ulcers associated with tender inguinal
lymphadenopathy
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
The most likely diagnosis is chancroid, a sexually transmitted infection caused by
Haemophilus ducreyi

. Chancroid is characterized by the presence of deep, undermined, exudative, painful genital ulcers; tender inguinal lymph nodes, which often suppurate, are typically present. Chancroid is rarely seen in the United States.

figureCredits: Image reproduced from the CDC Public Health Image Library.

children: A 40-year-old man who returned from Belize 4 days ago is evaluated for fever, retro-orbital pain, myalgia, and severe lumbosacral pain. The skin changes
shown
occurred following insufflation of a blood pressure cuff.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is dengue fever. The appearance of a petechial rash following application of a blood pressure cuff, as seen in this patient, constitutes a positive “tourniquet test,” which supports the presence of microvascular fragility compatible with dengue fever. Dengue fever is the most prevalent arthropod-borne viral infection in the world. Endemic areas include Southeast Asia, the South Pacific, South and Central America, and the Caribbean. The incubation period is 4 to 7 days. Patients may be asymptomatic or present with an acute febrile illness associated with frontal headache, retro-orbital pain, myalgia, and arthralgia, with or without minor spontaneous bleeding. Severe lumbosacral pain is characteristic. As the fever abates, a macular or scarlatiniform rash, which spares the palms and soles, may develop and evolve into areas of petechiae on extensor surfaces.
A 31-year-old man is evaluated for a 3-week illness consisting of fever, dyspnea, and dry cough. He has risk factors for HIV infection.
Frontal chest radiograph is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
This patient mostly likely has
Pneumocystis jirovecii

pneumonia. The posterior-anterior chest radiograph shows diffuse bilateral airspace disease, characterized by ground-glass changes and minute nodules, with possible formation of small cysts. The infiltrates are predominantly in the middle lung zones. In an immunocompromised patient, these findings suggest
P. jirovecii
pneumonia.
P. jirovecii

pneumonia can, however, present with a wide range of radiographic findings, including lobar infiltrates, pneumothoraces, and normal images. A normal chest radiograph does not exclude the diagnosis; when clinically indicated, chest CT is more sensitive, demonstrating patchy ground-glass opacities. Diagnosis can be confirmed by identification of stains of the organism in sputum or bronchoalveolar lavage fluid. The Gomori methenamine stain of the sputum
shows
the pneumocystis organism.
A 23-year-old woman with systemic lupus erythematosus is evaluated for headache, fever, and meningismus. She is receiving immunosuppressive therapy.
Cerebrospinal fluid Gram stain specimen is
shown
Which of the following organisms is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
The cerebrospinal fluid Gram stain specimen suggests a diagnosis of
Listeria monocytogenes
meningitis. The image demonstrates many gram-positive, rod-shaped organisms characteristic of
L. monocytogenes. Listeria
rods are typically short and may occur singly or in short chains. Additionally,
Listeria
may show gram-variable staining. These characteristics may lead to the mistaken identification on Gram stain as
Streptococcus pneumoniae
, enterococci, corynebacteria, or, when it stains variably,
Haemophilus
species.
L. monocytogenes
is an uncommon cause of meningitis in adults; however, the risk increases in older adults and those with altered cell-mediated immunity.

objective.__html: Diagnose Listeria monocytogenes in a cerebrospinal fluid Gram stain specimen.

children: A 42-year-old woman with HIV infection is evaluated for fever, confusion, and headache.
A contrast-enhanced CT scan of the head is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is toxoplasmosis. In immunocompromised patients (e.g., in those with advanced HIV infection), latent infection may reactivate and result in toxoplasmic encephalitis, which typically presents with multiple brain lesions that localize in the parietal or frontal lobes, in the thalamus or basal ganglia, or at the corticomedullary junction. Ring enhancement of the brain lesions occurs in approximately 90% of patients, and surrounding edema with mass effect is also present, as seen in this image.
Toxoplasma
infection in immunocompetent patients is usually asymptomatic or may present with bilateral, symmetric, nontender cervical lymphadenopathy; latent infection is frequently lifelong.

objective.__html: Diagnose toxoplasmosis based on head CT findings.

title: Question 40

children: A 31-year-old man is evaluated for hypotension. Over the past 48 hours, he has developed fever, diarrhea, acute kidney injury, thrombocytopenia, and the diffuse rash
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
The most likely diagnosis is toxic shock syndrome (TSS). The rash of TSS is a sunburn-like diffuse erythema that also involves the palms and soles and mucous membranes.
Staphylococcus aureus
– and
Streptococcus pyogenes

–associated exotoxins result in cytokine production that can result in TSS. Staphylococcal TSS is associated with tampon use, nasal packings, surgical wounds, skin ulcers, burns, catheters, and use of injection drugs. Streptococcal TSS is associated with skin and soft tissue infection, particularly necrotizing fasciitis. Clinical features of TSS may include chills, malaise, fever, hypotension, erythematous rash, and multiorgan involvement.

figureCredits: Image reproduced from the CDC Public Health Image Library.

children: A 44-year-old man is evaluated for fever and worsening back pain of 2 weeks' duration.
A radiograph of the spine is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is vertebral osteomyelitis. Typical findings in hematogenous vertebral osteomyelitis consist of destructive changes of two contiguous vertebral bodies with collapse of the intervening disk space. This image shows osteopenia of the affected vertebrae, loss of visible disk margins in some areas, narrowing of the disk space, and erosions into the vertebral bodies. The infection is rarely confined to a single vertebra; however, when this does occur, it can lead to collapse of the vertebral body, mimicking an ordinary vertebral compression fracture.

Plain radiography is not adequately sensitive to exclude a diagnosis of osteomyelitis, but it is recommended during initial evaluation because of the relatively low cost. The specificity of plain radiography is sufficient to confirm the diagnosis in most patients. If a plain radiograph is not diagnostic, MRI, with and without intravenous contrast, is preferred. If MRI cannot be obtained because of specific contraindications, CT with intravenous contrast is an alternative.
A 72-year-old man with dementia is evaluated for new-onset delirium.
Chest
radiographs
are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is left lower lobe pneumonia. This patient's chest radiographs demonstrate a left lower lobe infiltrate that is consistent with pneumonia as a cause of his dyspnea. Although the left lower lobe infiltrate is obscured by the heart shadow on the posterior-anterior view, the lateral view demonstrates the “spine sign,” in which the progressive increase in lucency of the lumbosacral vertebral bodies from superior to inferior is interrupted by increased radiographic density caused, in this case, by an infiltrate in the left lower lobe.
A patient is evaluated for erythema, warmth, pain, and swelling on the medial thigh. Ultrasonography is performed.
(Note that there is no sound for this
video
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis based on these ultrasound findings?

These ultrasound findings are consistent with an abscess. The round, hypoechoic (dark) object is a fluid-filled structure with evidence of hyperechoic debris inside. As the probe is moved along the skin, the structure is seen to be spherical and not tubular, as would be found in deep venous thrombosis.

Cellulitis findings on ultrasound appear as edema of the soft tissue with a “cobblestone” appearance and without a discrete collection of fluid. No significant amount of muscle is seen on this examination. However, if present, rhabdomyolysis may disrupt the normal fascicular architecture of muscle with both hypoechoic areas and areas of increased echogenicity.

objective.__html: Diagnose soft tissue abscess using point-of-care ultrasonography.

children: A 40-year-old woman is evaluated for fever and cough and new pulmonary infiltrate. She is receiving chemotherapy for acute myeloid leukemia.
A methenamine silver stain of a lung biopsy specimen is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely organism?
The most likely organism is
Aspergillus fumigatus
. The image demonstrates hyphal forms with acute-angle (45-degree) branching, characteristic of an
Aspergillus
species. Invasive pulmonary aspergillosis, the most serious form of
Aspergillus

infection, most often occurs in immunosuppressed patients who have neutropenia or received a hematopoietic stem cell transplant. This type of aspergillosis usually begins in the respiratory tract and then enters the circulatory system (angioinvasion). This is followed by the formation of a fungus-septic emboli complex with subsequent hematogenous dissemination. The most common manifestation of angioinvasive disease is pulmonary aspergillosis, but sinusitis, brain abscess, endocarditis, disseminated infection, and osteomyelitis also may occur.

objective.__html: Diagnose Aspergillus fumigatus in tissue obtained from an immunosuppressed patient.

title: Question 45

children: A 50-year-old woman is evaluated for fever, malaise, and the acute onset of the skin rash
shown
, which is associated with regional lymphadenopathy.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

This patient has facial erysipelas manifested as severe malar and periorbital bright erythema and swelling. Note the purulent discharge from the eye. Erysipelas refers to infection of the epidermis, upper dermis, and superficial lymphatics and is caused by the inoculation of the skin and subcutaneous tissue with streptococcal bacteria. Usually involving the face or lower extremities, this infection is brightly erythematous with distinct elevated borders and associated fever, lymphangitis, and regional lymphadenopathy.

figureCredits: Image reproduced from the CDC Public Health Image Library.

children: A 58-year-old man is evaluated for a
rash
on the right side of his abdomen that developed over the past 2 weeks.
Which of the following is most likely diagnosis?
The patient's skin finding is consistent with the erythema migrans rash that characterizes the early phase of infection with the spirochete
Borrelia burgdorferi
following an
Ixodes

tick bite. The early localized rash of Lyme disease generally occurs within the first month of infection at the site of the tick bite, often the belt line, inguinal region, popliteal fossa, or axilla. The rash expands over days to weeks, characteristically developing an area of central clearing with expansion (as seen in this patient) leading to a “bullseye” appearance. Some patients may have a small area of necrosis at the center of the rash, although this is less common.
A 41-year-old woman is evaluated for fever, headache, and meningismus.
Cerebrospinal fluid Gram stain specimen is
shown
Which of the following organisms is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
The most likely organism causing this patient's symptoms is
Streptococcus pneumoniae.
The cerebrospinal fluid shows gram-positive, lancet-shaped diplococci, which is characteristic of
S. pneumoniae
(pneumococcus). Bacterial meningitis usually presents with acute meningeal signs (fever, nuchal rigidity) and altered mental status. Since the introduction of conjugate vaccines, the incidence of
Haemophilus influenzae
and
Neisseria meningitides
meningitis has decreased, making
S. pneumoniae
the most common cause of community-acquired bacterial meningitis.

objective.__html: Diagnose Streptococcus pneumoniae in a cerebrospinal fluid Gram stain specimen.

children: A 51-year-old woman is evaluated for fever, jaundice, and anemia.
Peripheral blood smear is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is babesiosis. This peripheral blood smear shows an intracellular inclusion. Babesiosis and malaria should be considered in patients with intracellular erythrocyte inclusions, fever, and hemolytic anemia. A history of a tick bite is consistent with the transmission of babesiosis; whereas malaria is transmitted by the female Anopheles mosquito. The characteristic finding of babesiosis is the intraerythrocytic tetrad, or Maltese cross, as
shown
. In addition, vacuolated, pleomorphic rings without pigment or gametocytes are characteristic of
Babesia
infection.

objective.__html: Diagnose babesiosis based on peripheral blood smear findings.

title: Question 49

children: A 41-year-old woman is evaluated for fever and total loss of vision in the left eye. She also reports a 2-week history of sinus pain and rhinorrhea. The left nasal mucosa has gray-black exudate and an eschar. She has poorly controlled type 1 diabetes mellitus.
The left eye is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is mucormycosis. Symptoms and signs include headache, epistaxis, and ocular findings, including proptosis, periorbital edema, and decreased vision. A pathognomonic finding on physical examination is the presence of a black eschar on the nose or palate.

Mucormycosis is the third most frequent cause of invasive fungal infections in immunocompromised patients but is rarely seen in immunocompetent persons. Patients with neutropenia, diabetes mellitus, and acidosis are particularly at risk. The most common mucormycetes are
Rhizopus arrhizus
and
Mucor

species. Major blood vessels are invaded, with ensuing ischemia, necrosis, and infarction of adjacent tissues. Mucormycosis has five major clinical forms: (1) rhinocerebral; (2) pulmonary; (3) abdominal, pelvic, gastric, and gastrointestinal; (4) primary cutaneous; and (5) disseminated. This patient has rhinocerebral mucormycosis. This is a rapidly fatal infection that spreads from the sinuses retro-orbitally to the central nervous system. Mucormycosis is diagnosed by tissue biopsy and culture. Treatment requires emergent surgical debridement in addition to antifungals.

figureCredits: Image reproduced from the CDC Public Health Image Library.

title: Question 50

children: A 34-year-old man develops fever, malaise, conjunctivitis, coryza, cough, and a rash that first appeared on his face and then became generalized, as
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is measles. This patient has a morbilliform rash that developed because of a measles infection. The rash is typically erythematous and maculopapular and spreads cephalocaudally. In the first few days, the rash blanches. This image was captured on day 3 of the rash, which is usually when the rash manifests; the rash fades after 4 to 7 days in the order it appeared

figureCredits: Image reproduced from the CDC Public Health Image Library.

title: Question 51

children: A 27-year-old man is evaluated for painful inguinal
lymphadenopathy
. Four weeks ago, he had a painless ulcer on his penis that healed spontaneously.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
The most likely diagnosis is lymphogranuloma venereum, a urogenital infection caused by
Chlamydia trachomatis

. Primary infection is typically characterized by a genital ulcer that heals spontaneously. Secondary manifestations appear within 2 to 6 weeks and are characterized by infection of the inguinal and/or femoral nodes. This image depicts a close anterior view of a patient's right inguinal region, highlighting the presence of an enlarged inguinal lymph node, also known as a bubo. It is important to note the presence of a groove sign, caused by the extreme swelling of the lymph nodes pressing against the taught inguinal ligament, which causes a groove to form on the skin surface.

figureCredits: Image reproduced from the CDC Public Health Image Library.

children: A 36-year-old man with alcohol use disorder is evaluated for fever and cough.
Chest radiograph is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

This frontal chest radiograph shows a lung abscess. Radiographic findings include a cavitary pulmonary infiltrate, partial central clearing, and an air-fluid level; these findings are consistent with a lung abscess. The most common cause of lung abscess is aspiration, most typically in patients that experienced an episode of decreased consciousness. These abscesses are the result of polymicrobial infection. Lung abscesses can also result from infections with pyogenic bacteria, most commonly
Staphylococcus aureus
Klebsiella pneumoniae
, and
Pseudomonas aeruginosa

. Although an infected bulla could have a similar appearance, the thick wall of the lesion suggests a cavitary lung abscess rather than an infected bulla. Cavitary tuberculosis tends to be located in the apical segments of the upper and lower lobes and may be associated with hilar or mediastinal adenopathy.

objective.__html: Diagnose a lung abscess on a chest radiograph.

children: A 23-year-old woman is evaluated for a 4-day history of fever, headache, and myalgia. A rash appeared today. She completed a hike on the Appalachian Trail in North Carolina 12 days ago.
The rash is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is Rocky Mountain spotted fever. This patient presents with nonspecific symptoms after travel to the "Rocky Mountain spotted fever belt" between North Carolina and Oklahoma in the United States. The hallmark feature of Rocky Mountain spotted fever is a macular eruption around the ankles or wrists, with central spread and progression to petechiae or purpura; the rash may not appear until 2 to 4 days after symptoms begin.

title: Question 54

children: A 30-year-old woman is evaluated for a painless lesion on her
vulva
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is syphilis. The primary ulcerative lesion (chancre) in patients with syphilis develops approximately 3 weeks after infection occurs, has a clean appearance with heaped-up borders, and is usually painless. It is often unrecognized. The primary chancre resolves spontaneously, and, without treatment, the infection progresses to a more advanced stage.

objective.__html: Diagnose the chancre associated with primary syphilis.

figureCredits: Image reproduced from the CDC Public Health Image Library.

children: A 21-year-old woman is evaluated for the sudden appearance of a painful
rash
on her arm.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection. Classically, HSV types 1 and 2 initially cause a cluster of pink papules that rapidly become vesicular. Grouped vesicles (small, clear, fluid-filled blisters) on an erythematous, edematous base are characteristic. They often become cloudy pustules before rupturing, leaving behind the clustered erosions
shown
that usually completely involute within 3 to 5 days.

objective.__html: Diagnose cutaneous herpes simplex virus infection.

children: A 59-year-old man is evaluated for fever, a 6.8-kg (15-lb) weight loss over the past 7 weeks, fatigue, malaise, and productive cough, occasionally with blood.
Chest radiograph is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is tuberculosis. The frontal chest radiograph demonstrates bilateral upper lobe infiltrates with cavitation. Reactivation (postprimary) pulmonary tuberculosis may be associated with thin-walled cavities or cavities found within an area of patchy airspace opacity. Most tuberculin pulmonary cavities do not contain fluid, but up to 20% may demonstrate an air-fluid interface because of bacterial superinfection or bleeding.

A 48-year-old woman is evaluated for a 3-day history of fever and nonbloody diarrhea occurring several times a day. She recently completed a 7-day course of cephalexin for cellulitis of the leg. She also has a history of Crohn colitis.
Results of colonoscopy are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
The most likely diagnosis is
Clostridioides difficile

colitis, as evidenced by pseudomembranes (severe inflammation of the inner lining of the colon) seen on this patient's colonoscopy. Diagnosis is usually established by testing stool from persons who have unexplained new-onset diarrhea occurring 3 or more times day. In general, colonoscopy is not performed in patients with typical disease and positive laboratory evaluation. Colonoscopy may be useful if an alternative diagnosis is suspected that requires direct visualization and biopsy.
A 54-year-old man develops fever unresponsive to antibiotic therapy. He has prolonged neutropenia following chemotherapy.
CT scan of the chest is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

This chest CT scan suggests an invasive fungal infection, such as aspergillosis. The CT scan shows a nodular opacity with poorly defined borders and surrounding ground-glass opacification. This appearance, referred to as a “halo sign,” is an early radiographic finding in patients with aspergillosis. The ground-glass appearance surrounding the fungal nodule indicates hemorrhage into the surrounding lung tissue. In the appropriate clinical setting, such as neutropenia, the halo sign may indicate aspergillosis or other angioinvasive fungal infection, including fusariosis and zygomycosis. A malignant nodule would be more likely to be spiculated and not have the halo appearance.

objective.__html: Diagnose invasive aspergillosis on a CT scan of the chest.

children: A 33-year-old woman is evaluated for acute onset of productive cough and fever.
Chest
radiographs
are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is right lower lobe pneumonia. This patient's chest radiographs reveal a right lower lobe infiltrate. An opacification is seen in the right lower lung field on the posteroanterior chest radiograph. Notably, the infiltrate does not obscure the right lateral heart border, suggesting that the infiltrate is within the right lower and not the right middle lobe. On the lateral film, a posterior and inferior infiltrate is identified by the increased density over the vertebral bodies rather than the normal progressive decrease in density going inferiorly (the “spine sign”). Together, these findings localize the infiltrate to the right lower lobe and are consistent with right lower lobe pneumonia.

objective.__html: Identify a right lower lobe infiltrate on a chest radiograph.

children: A 59-year-old man is admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure caused by severe community-acquired pneumonia.
A sputum specimen Gram stain is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely organism responsible for this patient's community-acquired pneumonia?
The sputum Gram stain specimen demonstrates gram-positive, lancet-shaped diplococci, a finding characteristic of
Streptococcus pneumoniae

(pneumococcus). Diagnostic studies to identify a causative organism are not routinely indicated in outpatients with community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) but should be considered in non-ICU hospitalized patients when this information would alter therapy or allow treatment de-escalation. All patients with CAP who require admission to the ICU should undergo diagnostic evaluation to confirm a microbial cause. Interpretation of sputum Gram stain and culture is hampered by the presence of oropharyngeal colonization, and growth may reflect nonpathogenic organisms. A good-quality sputum culture obtained before antibiotic initiation is suggestive or diagnostic in up to 80% of cases of pneumococcal pneumonia; sensitivity decreases after antibiotic therapy.

objective.__html: Diagnose Streptococcus pneumoniae on a sputum specimen Gram stain.

title: Question 61

children: A 25-year-old woman is evaluated for fever, generalized lymphadenopathy, and the painless genital lesions
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
The most likely diagnosis is secondary syphilis. This patient has condylomata lata lesions involving the vulva and anal region, caused by
Treponema pallidum

. Condylomata lata can be a manifestation of secondary syphilis and present as painless, gray, raised papules appearing on the vulva and near the anus, or in any other warm, moist areas, such as the mouth or intertriginous regions. Condylomata lata are typically located near the primary chancre. These lesions are very infectious.

objective.__html: Diagnose condylomata lata and its association with secondary syphilis.

figureCredits: Image reproduced from the CDC Public Health Image Library.
